Award.AwardTitle: Contribution of Biogenic Volatile Organic Compounds to Organic Aerosol Formation in the Presence and Absence of Anthropogenic Pollution
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop a better understanding of the formation and transformation of Secondary Organic Aerosol (SOA) and will examine how Biogenic Volatile Organic Compounds (BVOC) interact with anthropogenic pollution to alter the atmosphere's oxidative capacity and enhance SOA formation. Hourly measurements will be made, using a Semi-Volatile Thermal desorption Aerosol Gas chromatograph (SVTAG) system, of speciated vapor and particle phase intermediate and semi-volatile organic compounds during the Southern Oxidant and Aerosol Study (SOAS) to be conducted in Alabama in the summer of 2013. The time-evolution of secondary organic compounds and their precursors will be studied a smog chamber and compared with data from the SOAS campaign to ascertain whether mechanisms observed in the smog chamber are supported by the field data.

This study will make a significant contribution to understanding the formation of secondary organic aerosol in a heavily forested region with natural emissions of volatile organic compounds. Emissions of air pollutants from urban areas may enhance secondary aerosol formation. The data collected in this project will be critical to advancing the knowledge and prediction of regional atmospheric chemistry, ozone and secondary aerosol production, and their role in climate processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Southeast Oxidant and Aerosol (SOAS) campaign focused on elucidating the role of biogenic volatile organic compound (BVOC) emissions in atmospheric chemistry and climate, and understanding how the transformation and fate of BVOC is altered by the presence of anthropogenic pollution sources. This large scale collaborative study was designed to comprehensively examine how BVOC emissions and their interaction with anthropogenic pollution alter the atmosphere’s oxidative capacity, influence secondary organic aerosol (SOA) formation, atmospheric composition and, ultimately, affect the earth’s radiation balance and climate.

We contributed to the study specifically through making speciated measurements of semivolatile organic matter, including both gas and particle phases, with in-situ hourly observations with our Semi-Volatile Thermal desorption Aerosol Gas chromatograph (SVTAG) instrument. The data have been included in multiple publications, are publicly available in the SOAS campaign data archive, and have been widely used by collaborating scientists from other research groups. In addition, we collected aerosol samples on quartz filters at 4-hour time resolution during the whole field campaign (approximately 250 samples). The filters were analyzed off-line using a unique instrument in our laboratory (multidimensional GC with both electron impact and vacuum ultraviolet ionization coupled to high mass resolution time-of-flight mass spectrometry (GCxGC/HR-VUV,EI-TOFMS). The results included a 4-hour time-resolved database of approximately 800 chemical species defining the chemical composition of organic aerosols in the southeastern U.S.

These data sets were examined to assess the factors controlling gas particle partitioning of oxidation products, and the differences in the reaction pathways for SOA formation from BVOC in the presence and absence of anthropogenic influence. We focused most of our analyses on measurements of a suite of chemicals that have previously been identified as major tracers for BVOC oxidation in both polluted and clean environments, and we simultaneously endeavored to dramatically increase the range of chemicals observed and identified.

Exchange of atmospheric organic compounds between gas and particle phases is important in the production and chemistry of particulate matter but is poorly understood due to a lack of simultaneous measurements in both phases of individual compounds. Measurements of particle and gas phase organic compounds are reported here for Centreville, Alabama, a forested area in the Southeastern United States influenced by anthropogenic pollution.. Polyols formed from isoprene oxidation contribute 8% on average to particle-phase organic mass but are also observed to have substantial gas-phase concentrations contrary to many models that treat these compounds as nonvolatile. The broader results show that the gas-particle partitioning of approximately 100 known and newly observed oxidation products is not well explained by environmental factors (e.g., temperature). Compounds of high- volatility have higher particle fractions than expected from state-of-the-art models. These observations support the conclusion that many commonly measured biogenic oxidation products may be bound in low-volatility mass (e.g., accretion products, inorganic− organic adducts) that remains to be chemically resolved.

The chemical complexity of atmospheric organic aerosol (OA) has caused substantial uncertainties in understanding its origins and environmental impacts. We provide new constraints on OA origins through novel compositional characterization with molecular-level details. Our results suggest that SOA from monoterpene oxidation accounts for approximately half of summertime OA in Centreville, Alabama. We find that different chemical processes involving nitrogen oxides (some of anthropogenic origin), during days and nights, play a central role in determining the mass of monoterpene SOA produced. These findings elucidate the strong anthropogenic-biogenic interaction affecting ambient aerosol in the Southeastern United States and point out the importance of reducing anthropogenic emissions, especially under a changing climate, where biogenic emissions will likely keep increasing.

This study made a significant contribution to understanding the formation of SOA in a heavily forested region with natural emissions of volatile organic compounds. Emissions of air pollutants from urban areas were observed to enhance secondary aerosol formation. Coupled with other co-located measurements, these data have been used to understand BVOC emission, oxidation, and particle formation pathways at the molecular level, to understand how these pathways change when influenced by anthropogenic sources, and their importance for the atmospheric budget of aerosols and the earth’s radiation balance on regional scales.
